Under the restrictions, no public transport services including operation of taxis, auto-rickshaws will be permitted in these seven districts. The exception will include transport of all kinds to and from hospitals, airports, railway station, bus terminals or bus stands and for the purpose essential services.

People are required to stay at home and come out only for basic services while strictly following social distancing guidelines. All foreign returnees are directed to remain under strict home quarantine for a period as decided by health authorities, the order stated.

Prohibitory orders will remain in place banning a gathering of five or more people in public places. A transport plan shall be prepared by concerned Deputy Commissioners for the services of essential commodities, it further stated.

The Resident Welfare Associations shall take necessary measures for social distancing and for maintaining essential services. If any violation found, same shall be informed to police control room by RWAs. Any person found violating the containment measures shall be deemed to have committed an offence punishable under Section 188 of IPC (Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), the order added.

The State Government has also deputed six IAS offices in these districts for planning, coordination and monitoring the implementation of all activities for the prevention and control of spread of COVID-19. IAS Varinder Singh Kundu will look after Gurugram district, Anand Mohan Sharan is given responsibility of Sonepat, Vineet Garg is deputed in Panipat, Deepti Umashankar in Panchkula, D Suresh in Rohtak and Jhajjar, Sanjay Joon in Faridabad.

Meanwhile, the Chief Minister Manohar Lal on Sunday said the Janta curfew, which was practiced on the call of the Prime Minister Narendra Modi was successful.

He said that necessary services such as hospital services, medical services, health services, electricity and water services, vegetable markets, general grocery services, etc. will be allowed in the state. Similarly, agriculture-related goods and essential services will be continued so that farmers do not face any kind of problem as the farmers are working to handle their harvest, he assured.

The Chief Minister praised the cooperation made by the RWA and NGOs and said that such organizations are working hand-in-hand with the government in preventing the spread of COVID-19 and it is commendable.

He said that 75 districts have been locked down in the country, and similarly we have also locked down seven districts of the state, namely, Gurugram, Faridabad, Sonipat, Panipat, Jhajjar, Rohtak, Panchkula.

He appealed to the people of the seven districts, to maintain discipline till March 31 as all the institutions will remain closed except essential services. However, there is no need of panic or fear, he added.

The Chief Minister further said that he is sure that the country is very close to control the further spread of the virus.

Expressing hope he said, "I think we are very close in this struggle and that we are soon going to get the news to bring the upward trend of spread of the virus towards a flat trend and then to downward trend. It is our responsibility as citizens, as a society and as a human race, that we remain strong, take a pledge and move forward determined so as to fulfill our responsibilities."

Hry issues order to restrict staff strength in govt. offices

All the Administrative Secretaries shall ensure that 50 percent of Group B, C and D employees are required in their departments (including Municipal Bodies, Corporations and Societies) to attend the office every day and the remaining 50 percent staff be directed to work from home (headquarters and in the field offices in all districts). A weekly roster of duty of Group B, C and D should be finalized and the employees shall be asked to attend the office on alternate weeks, stated a government’s order.

Entry of visitors would be restricted in the offices and social distancing norms and all precautions should be followed, the order stated.

The order shall not apply to Municipal Bodies and Corporations and Departments including Chief Secretary, Revenue, Health, Home, Agriculture, Public Health, Development and Panchayat, Power, Irrigation, Urban Local Bodies, Medical Education, Information and Technology, Cooperation, Finance, Excise and Taxation, Information and Public Relations and Food and Civil Supplies.

Title: Chandigarh admn orders lockdown till March 31
Article:
With Chandigarh reporting sixth positive case of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) on Sunday morning, the UT Administration ordered a lockdown imposing restrictions till March 31 including suspension of public transport to prevent the spread of infection.

“All shops, commercial establishments, offices and factories, workshops, godowns etc shall close their operations from March 22 till March 31. All public transport shall remain suspended. However, essential services including vegetable shops, ration shops, chemists etc shall remain open,” stated an order issued by Chandigarh Administration.

Prohibitory orders have also been imposed in Chandigarh banning gathering of five or more people. The order came into force from March 22, will be effective till March 31.

These decisions were taken after a high-level meeting held by Punjab Governor and UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore through video conferencing on Sunday.

The sixth person tested positive in Chandigarh is 23 years old male, who is secondary contact of first COVID-19 positive case of the city. The person has been admitted in isolation ward in Government Medical College and Hospital, Sector 32 here.

He is the son of a senior officer of UT Administration and the entire family has now been home quarantined.

While the senior officer has been home quarantined, concerns were raised as he attended a series of meetings last week in Administration. His test report for COVID -19 was awaited till the filing of this report.

“Three family members of sixth positive case including father aged 52 years (senior UT officer), mother aged 48 years and sister aged 21 years have also been sampled for COVID 19 at GMSH Sector 16. The reports are still awaited,” said a senior officer of Administration.

Earlier, the mother, brother and cook of the first positive case of 23 years old woman resident of city, were tested positive on Friday and are under treatment in GMCH-32.

The health of all six positive cases is stable, said the UT officer.

The number of people put in home quarantine stood at over 400 people in the union territory of Chandigarh.

Meanwhile, as the 'Janata curfew' got underway at 7 am on Sunday, people largely kept themselves indoor as part of the social distancing exercise to stop the spread of the virus in Chandigarh.

All markets and establishments except those dealing in essential goods and services remained close in the city.

Restrictions placed in Chandigarh

“No public transport services including operation of taxis, auto rickshaws shall be permitted except transport of all kinds to and from hospitals, airports, railways stations, bus stands,” stated an order issued by Administration on Sunday.

All inter-state commercial transport shall be closed

All shops except essential services of groceries and chemists, commercial establishments, offices and factories, workshops, godowns etc shall close their operations till March 31.

Strict home quarantine shall be observed by all foreign returnees (who landed in India on or after March 9) and their contact persons at risk as decided by Health Department.

All such foreign returnees shall also mandatorily contact the Administration and register themselves for home quarantine, falling which they shall be liable for legal action.

Any gathering of more than five persons in public places shall also be prohibited.

The services including banks, ATMs, postal, telecom, petrol pumps, gas agencies, groceries, internet, telecom will not be affected due to the order.

Title: UT deputes senior officers to tackle emergency situation
Lockdown in urban areas across state till Mar 31
Article:
CM thanks people for success of voluntary curfew, asks them to brace for more lockdowns

Chief minister Bhupesh Baghel on Sunday addressed the people of the state and thanked them for observing of the voluntary curfew on Saturday and Sunday.

CM Baghel in his address thanked the people of the state addressing them as brothers and sisters, saying the people of Chhattisgarh observed the voluntary curfew wholeheartedly for the last two days.

“Not only in big cities, but even in smaller villages, people restricted themselves to their homes and fulfilled unprecedented social and national responsibilities,” Baghel said.

“It will be counted as an extremely important contribution towards the survival of the human race and in the battle against the corona virus epidemic,” he said.

He further said: “ With the cooperation of the people today, my belief has now been strengthened that in the next few weeks, if we fulfill our obligation in the same way, and remain in our own homes, then we will be able to fully defeat corona in Chhattisgarh as well as the entire country.”

The CM said the people of Chhattisgarh and the country have always shown a sense of dedication and patriotism in the times of trouble.

“We have taken many necessary decisions to stop the spread of coronavirus in Chhattisgarh. Lockdown or isolation has been considered as the only effective way to prevent coronavirus worldwide and they are also strictly following it.”

The Centre has stopped the passenger rail service until March 31, he said.

“To prevent the spread of the virus in Chhattisgarh too, we have decided to increase the curfew until March31 in the urban areas. During the period all offices, institutions, transport services and other activities will be closed.

“Essential services such as medical shops, kirana shops, general stores, vegetables, milk vend and petrol pumps will remain open. Along with this, electricity supply, water supply services, domestic gas supply service, municipal cleaning and waste disposal services and commercial transport services of essential commodities will continue to function as seamlessly as before,” he said.

“Citizens should dial toll-free number 104 for healthcare services and 112 for any other problem, : the CM added.

The chief minister said the decision is harsh but it is necessary to fulfill it for the survival of everyone.

“Your chief minister, the government and its entire establishment is with you in this time of crisis. I am confident that with the support of all of you, we will be able to overcome this epidemic.”

Title: COVID-19: Offence filed against three Kharsia residents
Article:
The Raigarh district administration Sunday filed an FIR against three people, all residents of Kharsia, who returned from a trip to Kazakhstan, for violating the government orders related to the coronavirus epidemic.

The FIR has been filed at Kharsia police station under Section 188 of the IPC and Section 3 of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897 (Penalty for disobeying any regulation or order made under the act).

The Raigarh district administration has imposed section 144(1) of CrPC within the district limits to contain the spread of coronavirus, as preventive step.

An order is already in place for people returning from foreign trips to report about their travel details to the state health department or stay in home-isolation. The district civil administration and police have to keep tab people who are in home-isolation.

Superintendent of police, Raigarh Santosh Kumar Singh received information that four Kharsia residents have returned from Almaty, Kazakhstan on March 19, after a trip to the East European country on March 14.

The Raigarh SP then directed the SDO (police) Kharsia, to take immediate action.

A joint team of the executive magistrate, the health department and the police visited the residences of the four people and issued directives to remain in home-isolation for 14-day as a preventive measure against the spread of Covid-19.

While one of the people remained in home-isolation, the other three violated the directives. On March 20 and 21 , the three visited public places and social events, the SP said.

The local residents informed the Raigarh SP of their movement following which the SP ordered a probe.

The SDOP Kharisa found that all three people had ventured out in public places, risking the lives of others , as Kazakhstan has a large number of Covid-19 cases.

The SP then ordered to the local police to file an FIR against three for violating all the norms even after they were asked to remain at home in isolation.

Title: Janata curfew brings life to a standstill in Chhattisgarh
Article:
People across Chhattisgarh overwhelmingly as life came to standstill in response to the Janata curfew call by Prime Minister Narendra Modi as part of a social-distancing effort to combat the coronavirus.

All commercial establishments, except some medical stores, remained closed across the state, including in the state capital Raipur and major cities of Durg, Bilaspur and Raigarh.

With Indian Railways decided not to operate trains on Sunday, the Raipur railway station, too wore a deserted look.

Bus services, including the state-run city buses remained off the roads. Other public transports, like auto-rickshaws, also remained off the roads.

People stayed indoors in all the big towns of the state in view of the prime minister's call to the nation to observe 'Janata curfew' from 7 am to 9 pm on Sunday as part of social distancing amid the coronavirus threat.

In Raipur, places of worship, including the famous Mahamaya temple, were closed.

Police personnel deployed all over the capital city, were seen wearing masks or covering their mouth and nose with handkerchiefs.

The state government earlier invoked Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code in all urban areas, including the Raipur Municipal Corporation, to discourage assembly of people in a bid to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

So far, there has been one confirmed case of coronavirus in the state.

Schools, colleges, universities, anganwadis (state-run women and child care centres), public libraries, swimming pools, cinema halls, multiplexes, water parks, malls, coaching centres, clubs, beauty parlours, spas and gyms, have been shut down across the state.

According to a senior state health official, of the total samples sent for testing until Saturday, one tested positive while 133 came out negative.

“Reports of 10 other samples were awaited,” he said.

The state government on Saturday ordered to keep all its offices, except those providing essential and emergency services, shut until March 31.

Liquor shops, bars and restaurants will be closed from March 23 to 25 across the state.

Operations of inter-state buses, both to and from the state, and city buses in urban areas have been stopped.

Title: New medical colleges to strengthen health services: BJP
Article:
The Chhattisgarh Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) on Sunday welcomed the Centre’s decision for granting three more medical colleges in state at Korba, Mahasamund and Kanker districts.

State BJP chief Vikram Usendi thanked Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union health minister Harsh Vardhan for sanctioning of the three new medical colleges for Chhattisgarh.

Usendi said the three medical colleges will provide opportunities for the youngsters to become doctors and also help in providing better healthcare services in the state.

“It will pave way to establish a milestone in establishing better healthcare standards in the state,” he said.

Usendi also thanked the Korba, Mahasamund and Kanker members of parliament for making efforts for setting the new medical colleges in the state.

With the sanction, the Centre has shown that it is following the ideology of development--‘sab ke saath sab ke vikas’ (with all for all).

Leader of Opposition Dharamlal Kaushik also welcomed the decision, saying that it would pave the path for providing better healthcare services in the state.

On Saturday, the Centre sanctioned the setting up of the three new medical colleges in the state.

The medical colleges will start functioning from the next academic session.

According to information, the three medical colleges will be set up at the district hospitals or referral hospitals of the districts.

An amount of Rs 325 crore has been sanctioned for each medical college.

The Centre and state share for it would be 60:40 percent for funding. A separate memorandum of understanding (MoU) will be signed by the state government with the Centre for setting up the medical colleges.

Title: Newborn stolen from G’pati DHH; police in dark
Article:
Even though 24 hours has passed since the theft of a four-day-old baby by an unidentified woman from the Gajapati District Headquarters Hospital here on Saturday, police are yet to make any headway in the case.

Reports said one Juhi Paika of Manikapur village under Nuagada block was admitted to the DHH after she developed labour pain and later gave birth to the baby.

On Saturday afternoon, an unidentified woman came to the Obstetrics and Gynaecology ward, took the baby from Juhi and told her that the doctor has asked her to take the baby with her.

Later, Juhi and another of her relatives went to the doctor and inquired about the child. The doctor said he didn’t ask any woman to bring the baby. Shocked, Juhi and hospital staffs frantically searched for the mysterious woman and the baby but failed to find them. Then, the baby’s father lodged a complaint with police.

Police during scrutiny of the hospital’s CCTV footage found that a woman fled with the baby. The cops have assured that the accused would be rounded up soon and the baby would be recovered.

Title: ‘Don’t stop blood donation camps’
Article:
The Orissa Voluntary Blood Donors’ and Motivators’ Association has urged the Government and all other authorities not to stop voluntary donation camps due to the coronavirus outbreak.

Association president Dillip Dashshama has suggested that organizers plan small voluntary notion camps can be held to avoid gathering.

“If blood collection will be stopped, thalassemia and sickle cell patients and accident victims will suffer a lot. Lack of blood will create more danger than corona,” viewed Dashsharma.

He said all authorities should take blood donation as emergency service and hold small size camps. He hailed the Government move for closure of shops, malls and bazaars as precautionary measures for prevention of spread of the deadly virus.

Title: Online education in time of corona and beyond
Article:
Unforeseen disasters can sometimes unleash the unimaginable situations, albeit unwittingly. Today businesses, economies, nations and human lives are reeling under coronavirus’ impact. Globally, the education of 300 million students has been disrupted. Almost every hour there are reports of shutdowns of educational institutions and schools.

But there’s a flip side to this dismal development: Online education businesses are registering a spike worldwide, and carbon footprints have dipped significantly as people are working out of homes and corporates are offering free online courses for employee upskilling. It’s new-age-education in the time of Corona!

Nearly 600,000 students travel overseas for their higher education every year. With COVID 19 the prospect of that happening anytime soon, is bleak. Online education be their savior at this critical time when the Coronavirus scrounge ravaging geographies.

There are some key challenges in the online education segment that cannot be resolved without active participation of all stakeholders—state and central governments, academic experts, industry, students and faculty. Some key developments include: Ensuring robust online access to faculty and students with live streaming facility, outsourcing, collaborating with apps and tapping into in-house technologies to facilitate online learning. The other factors include adapting courses to online mode with necessary tweaks and improvisation, facilitating lecture playbacks, harnessing live feedback, training faculty and students with a simple and effective communication plan. Is India prepared to handle these? Yes, because we have tremendous technology expertise and political will to tide through. Besides Digital India initiative, the recent move by our government to encourage more FDI in education, provide Rs 3,000 crore for skill development and recognize foreign online degrees for Indian students is a strong indicator, of this.

Let’s look at the India picture on online education. This segment is expected to leap from $ 247 million in 2016, to approximately $ 1.96 billion by 2021. That is a compound annual growth rate of 52%. The number of users enrolled for various online learning courses is estimated to grow to 1.6 million in 2016 to 9.6 million by the end of 2021. Indians are the second largest consumers on MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) like Coursera. Government initiatives like SWAYAM, E- Basta, E-Pathshaala, Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyaan ( RMSA) etc. are furthering the spread of online education.

In India, the online education revolution has been brewing for a while, with rapid global technological advances in the backdrop. Conservative academic leadership, archaic regulations and lack of understanding has held it back. It is unfortunate that a crisis like the one we are facing now was needed to bring this issue in the forefront. In the current situation universities and institutions are scrambling to find solutions to problems created by themselves. In contrast several leading universities globally have seamlessly transitioned to online learning. My daughter who is pursuing a Psychology Honors degree at Kings College has returned to India (yes under quarantine now) and is learning online like her global peers, without any disruption. The college has also indicated that the assessment and evaluation would be done online too. That shows progressive thinking. Incidentally Kings college is ranked in the top 50 universities in the world!

Progressive educational institutions are rising to the challenge and setting inspiring examples of generous leadership. In wake of the current situation, a leading international online education player, is making its over 3,000 courses free for students, worldwide. This means students get access to 95 percent free data from top universities like Yale, Michigan and Johns Hopkins.

Few Indian institutions that have been able to successfully incorporate online learning include Pearl Academy, the country’s premier design school, where undisrupted learning is happening despite the education lockdown. Another university that comes to mind is University of Petroleum and Energy Sciences (UPES) based at Dehradun where learning continues through online medium. It’s clear that Pearl Academy and UPES had unlocked their mindsets many years back which enables them to make a seamless transition. What did these two institutions do differently? They recognized the need far ahead of others and made sure that right investments were made in technology, training of faculty and students. Myths around online learning were removed, high quality content was created and partnerships with global players like Coursera was forged to ensure a top-notch student experience. Students at Pearl and UPES have access to nearly 3,600 courses from top global universities like Brown, Duke, Michigan, Insead, NYU etc.

Both Institutions rather than going for free off the shelf learning systems invested in Blackboard which is the gold standard in online learning. These initiatives have paid off and today these two institutions are functioning seamlessly while others struggle. This learning can be replicated in other institutions across India, with government support. This includes setting basic paraments in online learning like–Strategic planning, outlining expectations from students and faculty, ensuring digital equilibrium, establishing daily flexible routines for students and faculty, planning courses and delivery, assignments and evaluations. India can do it!

We are in an interesting stage. We have all the drivers and the need for online education. Consider the following which have a significant bearing on online education in the future:

*** India has about 3.5 million students in higher education and around 900 universities catering to this need. In 2030 we will have around 14 million students that’s a 4x increase. To cater to this, we will need four times the number of universities, colleges and teachers – will we be ready? Can we be ready without online education playing an instrumental role in this.

***Centennials act, behave, consume and learn differently. They have the same romance with Phones and tablets that we have with books. Let’s acknowledge that and allow them to learn the way they want and not force our way of teaching. Learning on demand is a reality that we need to accept. According to UK India business council report, 75% of Indians online are under the age of 34, and almost half of them are under 24.

*** By 2022, India faces a potential shortage of 250 million skilled workers across sectors – EY/FICCI report)- Online has the potential to fill the gap substantially.

*** Convergence in HE & Corporate e-learning needs: Large number of corporates to embrace MOOC at the cost of proprietary-developed content for internal learning.

The opportunity for online learning is now. Corona virus has given a unique opportunity to drive deep impactful changes. Educational institution who still resist this change are less likely to grow. Radical change is needed in mindset, policy and conviction. We have welcomed technology in every sphere of our life and it has made a tremendous positive impact. Our digital natives are ready to dive into the fray for online learning too.

It’s the time to change perceptions and myths about online education. The government should take a note of this and invest in making an online education policy that allows access, focuses on quality and enables the country to reach a gross enrolment ration in the high 70s which will transform the country forever. Corona may be the catalyst but the openness to online learning and teaching should not end with Corona. The conversation needs to continue with tangible action on the ground to make a difference. An educated society is a liberated one and it is time we give wings to India. Wings of change through technology.

Title: Afflictions of the Mind
Article:
Bhagavad Gita has discussed in detail various evils which cause the human suffering. It has also been analysed as to why do these afflictions arise and how can they be managed.

Lord Krishna has identified lust, anger and greed as the three culprits which lead to one’s downfall. Hence, in shloka 16.21, He has termed them as three entry gates of hell. Further, He has cautioned that they lead to degradation of the soul and, therefore, should be abandoned.

In the next shloka i.e. in shloka 16.22, He has again emphasised the need for overcoming these vices. It is stated that the one who is freed from these three gates of darkness, he does what is good for himself ; and thus attains to the supreme destination.

Gita has examined as to why and how do the evils arise. It has been explained in shlokas 2.62 and 2.63 that thinking about sense objects produces attachment towards them. Attachment breeds desire, and non-fulfilment of desire leads to anger. And anger breeds delusion which leads to loss of memory and, in turn, decline in intelligence. Destruction of intelligence leads to one’s ruination.

These two shlokas have analysed the functioning of human mind very precisely. Depending upon whether one gets pleasure or pain from an object, he develops a like or dislike for that object. Object here obviously includes a person or any other thing that impacts the concerned senses and the mind. Such like or dislike i.e. attachment gives rise to desire - desire to get that object or to get rid of it.

Desire has the potential of giving rise to many ills. When it becomes excessive, selfish, unreasonable and beyond any control ; it then degenerates into lust. The lust shows itself in many forms - the urge for sexual excesses, the craving for wealth, physical impulses, hunger for social prestige and the drive for power etc. etc.

Unfulfilled desire results in anger and fulfilled desire leads to greed. When deluded by anger, one loses touch with reality and creates a false impression about himself and his situation. Delusion leads to loss of memory i.e. in the moments of anger one forgets the lessons learnt from the past experiences. Thus, one fails to discriminate between right and wrong. Such destruction of intelligence results in one’s downfall.

As is evident from the above discussion, all the three vices described here originate from the same source i.e. likes and dislikes and the consequent desires. The likes and dislikes and the resultant desires, though the root cause of all the vices, are not evil in themselves. Problem is created only when one is swayed by them.

Mischiefs of lust have been elaborated in shlokas from 3.36 to 3.39. When asked by Arjuna as to what impels man to commit sin even against his own will, as if by force ; Krishna replied that sin is committed due to lust. The lust is born of the mode of passion (rajas guna) and it later emerges as anger. It is all-devouring and most sinful enemy of man. Lust envelops the wisdom of the wise. It is their constant enemy because like fire, it has an insatiable appetite.

In shlokas from 3.40 to 3.43, it has further been explained as to where does the lust reside and how can it be controlled. It has been stated that the lust resides in senses, mind and the intelligence. Through them, it clouds the wisdom and deludes the embodied soul. As a result, one becomes a slave of the lust and is prepared to do anything to satisfy it. To break the stranglehold of the lust, one (the embodied soul) must manage the mind through intelligence and must not let the senses become slaves of lust. The senses must be controlled from the very beginning.

In other words, one should always remain vigilant and should not let his intelligence be carried away by lust.

Lust, anger and greed have been termed by Krishna as three gates of hell because they have the potential of generating many other similar evils. They keep on festering in the mind and prepare a fertile ground for other vices to grow there.

Ignorance, fear, arrogance, false ego, hypocrisy, doubting nature, excessive pride, anxiety, malice and envy, hate, ill will and enmity towards others ; and harshness are some of the other afflictions which have been identified in different shlokas of Bhagavad Gita. They continue to trouble the mind in one way or the other.

The importance of bringing the evils under control has also been emphasised in shloka 5.23 wherein it has been stated that the one who becomes capable of withstanding the urge of lust and anger before giving up his body i.e. in this very life, he is a yogi and he alone is a happy man. Though only lust and anger have been mentioned here in this shloka, it obviously applies to all the vices.

To summarise, the more a person is released from the clutches of evils, the more he becomes pure and capable of realising inner peace. He experiences joy from within.

Title: Punjab orders lockdown till Mar 31, total 21 positive cases
Article:
Sec 144 imposed; hospitals, pharmacies, banks, ATMs, media, petrol pumps, groceries, e-commerce exempted

With the State recording eight more positive cases of deadly Coronavirus in a day, Punjab Government on Sunday ordered a state-wide lockdown from Monday 6 am till March 31 as an emergency measure to tackle the worsening COVID-19 situation.

All essential services, including electricity, water and municipal services, banks and ATMs, media, postal and courier services, departmental stores, supermarkets and all other daily needs, hospitals, nursing homes, doctors, chemist shops, optical stores and pharmaceuticals manufacturing, petrol pumps, LPG gas, among others will be available during the shutdown.

The State Government has clarified that there will be “no curfew” during the lockdown period, but restrictions under Section 144 will be imposed preventing an assembly of more than 10 persons in a public space at any given time.

Earlier, there was a complete and partial lockdown in seven Coronavirus-hit districts of the state. However, employees of essential services such as banks and post offices and government employees would work on a rotation basis, which will not be more than 50 per cent of the strength in their offices.

Among the departments excluded from the shutdown were medical, health, police, jails, transport, electricity and water.

At the same time, the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh appealed to all residents to observe all health safeguards, especially frequently washing hands, and to avoid leaving their homes unless there is an acute emergency.

“You can play the most vital role in preventing further transmission of the disease by not stepping out,” said Capt Amarinder in his appeal to the people, adding, “During this period, all commercial establishments and shops shall remain closed except those dealing in essential commodities like food, grocery, medicines, etc.

All essential services such as water supply, sanitation and electricity shall be maintained. Restrictions on public transport imposed earlier will continue till March 31.”

Chief Secretary Karan Avtar Singh has directed Deputy Commissioners of all districts to ensure strict implementation of the restrictions. Health Department has also made it clear that all persons are required to stay at home, and they may leave home only if necessary for obtaining essential services or items or for employment or duty.

To ensure strict implementation of restrictions under Section 144, DGP Dinkar Gupta said that extra forces were being deployed in all districts.

The Chief Minister said that those residents, who have recently returned from abroad, are required to undergo home quarantine and report to the nearest Government health facility in case there is onset of any symptoms. The local community must also assist the administration in enforcing this in larger public interest, he appealed.

Capt Amarinder also appealed to trade and businesses not only to ensure adequate supplies of essential commodities but to avoid hoarding and profiteering of any kind. “It is important that we provide these commodities to our people at reasonable prices,” he said, warning that government “will not allow anyone to take undue advantage of the situation for their personal gains”.

In the official notification, the Chief Secretary ordered shutdown of all establishments to break the transmission chain of contagion of COVID-19 “for which it is necessary to prevent or minimise close contact amongst all persons”.

“Henceforth, all Deputy Commissioners or District Magistrates would issue orders under section 144 of CrPc or under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, for shutdown of all establishments except those providing essential services or items in districts from Monday, March 23, (6 am) till Tuesday, that is March 31 (inclusive),” the Chief Secretary notified, which was followed by individual notifications by the respective DCs of all districts.

The Chief Secretary’s notification stated that each DC may add any other essential item or service to the list as per local requirements to minimise disruption and ensure essential supplies. It has been clarified that the DCs will allow all ancillary activity for each item of essential services, such as delivery of newspapers by hawkers.

At the same time, the Health Department has clarified that during lockdown period, all private establishments such as shops, offices, factories, workshops etc but excluding godowns and warehouses, shall remain closed.

Further, no public transport services (passenger) including operation of taxis or auto-rickshaws etc shall be permitted except transport of all kinds to and from hospitals, airports, railway stations, bus terminals or bus stands.

In this context, it said that specific routes to be allowed in districts shall be decided by respective DCs.

Transport Department may operate essential skeleton services of State Transport Undertaking to ensure essential services, it said adding that all inter-state commercial passenger transport (buses) shall be closed.

The Health Department has also made it clear that strict home quarantine, for 14 days (excluding the day of arrival in India), shall be observed by all foreign returnees (who landed in India on or after March 7, 2020) and their contacts or other persons at risk, as decided by the District Administration.

All such foreign returnees shall also mandatorily contact the District Administration (on 104 or 112) and register themselves for home quarantine and download the COVA Punjab Mobile App), failing which they shall be liable for legal action.

FOLLOW GOVT DIRECTIONS: APPEALS AKAL TAKHT JATHEDAR

Sikhs’ highest temporal seat, Akal Takht’s Jathedar Giani Harpreet Singh on Sunday called upon the Sikh community to follow government’s directions to prevent spread of Coronavirus, besides appealing to the people to come forward and extend all kinds of help to needy persons. He has also asked for postponing religious ceremonies at all gurdwaras for two weeks.

Jathedar (head priest), in his video message, has asked the people to stay at home and enforce self-quarantine measures. “People should follow the directions of the government and health departments,” he said.

“All Sikh organizations and Gurdwara management committees across the world should step forward and extend all kinds of help including distribution of essential items and medicines to the needy,” he said while asking for preparing ‘sarais at Gurdwaras for quarantine purposes.

MASSIVE RESPONSE TO PM’S JANTA CURFEW,

From empty roads to beating of plates and clapping, the Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ‘Janta Curfew’ received massive response across Punjab.

The streets, markets, bus-stands, railway stations across Punjab, especially in Patiala, Nawanshahr, Faridkot, Bathinda, Moga, among other districts, wore deserted look as residents chose to remain indoor to combat Coronavirus.

In the evening, as the clock struck five, people came out of their houses in balconies, lawns, or terrace to show solidarity and express appreciation for the medical and other staff which is on the frontline of the battle against the Coronavirus and providing essential services to the people.

HOLLA MOHALLA VISITORS APPEALED TO GO UNDER ISOLATION

Deputy Commissioners of Bathinda and Ferozepur on Sunday appealed the residents who had visited Holla Mohalla event between March 6 to 9 at Sri Anandpur Sahib to stay in isolation at their house or report to the nearest hospital for testing of Coronavirus.

Special teams have been formed to trace out all those people who attended Hola Mohalla with the help of public announcements in villages and urban areas so that their testing can be ensured. Help of sarpanchs and municipal councillors is being sought to motivate all those devotees for the testing.

At the same time, appeal has also been made to the people who have been to Dera Niraml Bunga Kutia in Pathlava village to come forward for testing and stay inside their homes.

The appeal came after the reports of state’s lone corona positive deceased, Baldev Singh, visiting Holla Mohalla and meeting people at Dera came forward. Notably, 14 close contacts of Baldev Singh have been tested positive so far..

Title: EIGHT NEW CASES IN A DAY, TOTAL 21
Article:
Punjab on Sunday reported eight fresh positive cases of COVID-19 in a day, taking total number of cases in the State to 21. Out of these, seven new positive cases are from the family of Nawanshahr-resident Baldev Singh, who died on March 18 due to cardiac arrest and found Coronavirus positive later.

With this, total 14 close contacts of 70-year-old, who returned India on March 7 from Germany via Italy, acquired deadly virus through him. Those tested positive on Sunday include septuagenarian’s two close contacts at Chikka village in Nawanshahr and five relatives — comprising grandchildren. Already, his three sons, daughter-in-law, daughter, and 17-year-old granddaughter were tested positive on Saturday.

Confirming, Nawanshahr Civil Surgeon Dr Rajinder Bhatia said that health authorities carried out tests of 17 people and 14 of them have tested positive so far. “The administration has sealed Sujjon and Chikka villages from where these patients belonged to prevent the further spread of the virus,” said Deputy Commissioner Vinay Bublani.

In all, 14 positive cases have been reported from Nawanshahr alone, Out of total 21 confirmed cases across Punjab, with 88 people under home-quarantine in the district. Mohali has reported four, Hoshiarpur two and Amritsar has one positive patient.

“All positive cases have been placed under isolation in government hospital and are stable. The close contacts of all these cases have been put under quarantine and surveillance. Samples of close contacts of these cases have also been taken and sent to the designated labs for testing. Teams are working for surveillance,” said the government spokesperson.

Title: Complete lockdown in Kangra till further orders: CM Thakur
Article:
Himachal Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Sunday said that that as per the guidelines of the Union Government, the State Government has ordered complete lockdown of Kangra district till further orders.

The Chief Minister said that keeping in view the situation arisen due to the epidemic, the budget session of state Vidhan Sabha to commence from 2 pm on Monday, has been preponed for 11 am.

He said that there is adequate stock of essential commodities in the state and urged the people to not get panicked. The State Government is keeping a strict vigil over the situation and would take appropriate action as and when required, he added.

Notably, two people had tested positive for Coronavirus in Kangra on Friday. A woman who had returned from Dubai and a man who returned from Singapore had become the first cases of COVID-19 in the hill state.

Meanwhile, the Chief Minister thanked the people of the state for making the appeal of Prime Minister Narendra Modi of Xa day-long 'Janata curfew' in the country a grand success.

He said that all the people of the State remained indoor and no shops were opened and as per the report there was no sign of customers or passersby in any part of the state. This shows that like the people of other parts of the country, the people of the state also took the Prime Minister's appeal seriously and decided to stay in their homes. This appeal was made by the Prime Minister to break the cycle of the Coronavirus from spreading and help in combating the possible outbreak in the country, he added.

Title: PCC Chief expresses grief on martyrdom of Jawans
Article:
State Congress chief Mohan Markam on Sunday expressed grief on the martyrdom of security personnel at Kasalwad in Sukma districts of the state.

Markam in a statement, condoling the deaths of security personnel, said the Congress organization stood beside the families of the martyrs.

“They have laid down their lives while performing their duty and the act of Naxals was cowardice,” he said.

He had also prayed for the speedy recovery of the security personnel injured in the Naxal attacks.

Title: Silver lining to COVID-19 is that it is preventable
Article:
The Covid-19 pandemic is a challenge to human lives, health care system and the global economy. It is also a challenge to our mental well-being, as individuals and as a society. It has infected more than 2,55,000 people globally killing more than 10,000 with the number constantly rising.

Psychologists and psychiatrists are seeing many cases coming with signs of distress who are worried about Covid-19 infection and its consequences.

Sushil came to me for counselling and therapy with a sense of unease and paranoia in recent days. He was scared of dying of coronavirus, feeling delusional about microbes all around him beckoning him. He had insomnia and considerable anxiety. Stress is caused by fear of the disease compounded by social isolation as Governments are shutting down schools, offices, cinema halls and malls to restrict social interactions. Many psychiatrists cite an increase in requests for anti-anxiety medicines from patients or an increase in the dose of these medicines.

Covid-19 is a global pandemic which may have hazardous effects on human health. Its effects may range from a mild attack with negligible or mild symptoms to severe symptoms and sometimes death which may be seen in a small percent of cases, especially among the elderly and the medically compromised. People are stressed and come to us for treatment with anxiety, panic, hoarding, paranoia, aggression and depression.

Many have anti-social behaviours like anger, frustration and irritation. But the silver lining with covid-19 is that it is preventable. Prevention is the best possible cure for coronavirus infection— and can keep full blown corona infection at bay.

First and foremost there is extreme fear in the mind of people and the cause of this fear is that they are consciously or subconsciously linking the infection to immediate or subsequent death.

This is a myth which needs to be broken as it has been seen that 97% coronavirus infected patients have been found to recover with or without treatment which if given is just a symptomatic form of treatment, and only about 3% succumb to it— these are the patients who have uncontrolled diabetes or have other coronary or heart disease or respiratory disease or are old or have other medical complications.

The need of the hour is to pay attention to the preventive measures. We should be aware and take adequate preventive measures like frequent hand washing, social distancing, not touching our face frequently, and keeping surfaces clean to contain the contagion. Dry cough and fever could be symptoms of coronavirus so one should consult a doctor when experiencing this. However, there is a cluster of other infections like—sore throat, rhinitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, asthama - which resemble a corona infection and are also very common and prevalent today.

To be able to cope well and be safe we need to have a sane and stress-free mind. Many are suffering from extreme fear and emotional psychological and behavioral health effects. Social media is also proving to be a culprit in adding up to our stress levels now. It is full of posts and videos about coronavirus and some of these posts and memes are adding fuel to the fire of our psychological distress. Do not pay heed to these posts but to rely on authentic data from reliable sources like the WHO or UNICEF or Government notices, for correct information. Follow whatever your Government wants you to do as your cooperation with the Government at this stage can stop the further spread of this disease. A stressed mind decreases our immunity and makes us more vulnerable to the virus attack.

Lets be kind, cautious, courteous, considerate, caring and compassionate to others in these testing times. Meanwhile let us take advantage of this break from going out which we have got and focus on being happy and spending time with our friends and family. Lets plan and visualise good things and times ahead which we plan to do in future. Let us clean up our rooms closets, exercise and do all that we can do to build up our health and immunity. Lets remind ourselves that this time which we are spendig at home with our family has come as a blessing in disguise to us—let us be happy and make the most of it.

We need to focus on having a positive mindset, limit our social media time, soak in positive happy information, music ,movies, do yoga ,meditate ,see the rising sun, laugh and spread cheer all around us.

The Covid-19 pandemic is an opportunity to re-emphasize and reset our core values which we have all overlooked when all was going well. So lets reorganise our daily life and thoughts and make a daily effort to be stress free think positive be positive so that we can cope adaptively with the present situation and come out stronger from it. Together we must and we can.

To improve coping skills, limit screen time and news intake to once or twice a day and stay abreast of new guidelines but avoid news that triggers your panic button.Watch happy movies or video chat with family. Connect more deeply with Nature because now you have the time to do so. Look after your plants and pets.

Acknowledge your anxious thoughts rather than repressing them, then move on quickly.Tell yourself as soon as you notice that you are going into the anxiety zone—I am not going to go there now—and move on to other things. Health workers also exhaust themselves in such a crisis and they too should follow a stress management technique or they will have nothing to give to their patients except an empty hand and heart. Pray if you like and have faith and trust in God. Spirituality increases our resilience and makes us more self confident.

(The author is a neuro psychologist & founder of a crisis helpline)

Title: Lockdown: Plying of private vehicles restricted
Article:
Private vehicles would not be allowed to ply during the eight-day lockdown in five districts and eight towns of the State for containing the spread coronavirus), official sources said.

However, persons engaged in organisations or agencies permitted to operate during the period as listed in the Government’s official notification regarding the lockdown would be exempted from the restrictions. Such persons shall carry appropriate ID proofs and documents.

But the Government on Sunday clarified that goods vehicles are exempted from the restriction.

COVID-19 Chief Spokesperson Subroto Bagchi said, “In view of restrictions imposed by the Government for management of COVID-19 and for monitoring and smooth facilitation of movement of goods into the State and within the State, the Odisha Government has constituted a State-level monitoring unit on goods and services with immediate effect.”

In another development, the Government has decided to take stringent action against persons for violating the regulations framed to fight coronavirus. The violators can be booked under various sections of IPC for not complying with the regulatory orders.

A case can be registered against a person under Section 188 of IPC on charge of violating the order.

Action can be taken against the individuals under Sections 269 of IPC for doing something that may spread infection of any disease dangerous to life. In such cases, the accused may be imprisoned for six months or slapped with fine or both. However, the person can get bail for cognisable crime.

The police can arrest the violator under Section 270 of IPC for any act known to be likely to spread infection of any disease, which may pose threat to life. The accused may face a six-month imprisonment for the cognisable offence, or fine or both.

Moreover, arrest can be made against the persons under Section 271 of IPC for knowingly disobeying any quarantine rule. In such cases, the accused may be awarded imprisonment for six months or slapped with fine or both for the crime, which is non-cognisable. However, the offence is cognisable and bailable.

Title: Coupled with Janata Curfew, life standstill in entire State
Article:
An eight-day-long lockdown in five districts and eight towns in the State announced by Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik on Saturday in view of the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) began on Sunday.

Coupled with the public support for the Prime Minister Narendra Modi-called Janata Curfew across the country on Sunday, roads and markets throughout the State wore deserted looks.

Public transport vehicles stayed off the roads.

The lockdown is in force in the districts of Khordha, Cuttack, Ganjam, Kendrapada and Angul as well as in the towns of Puri, Rourkela, Sambalpur, Jharsuguda, Baleswar, Jajpur Road, Jajpur and Bhadrak from 7 am on March 22 till 9 pm on March 29.

“We have a very small window to take preemptive action. There is no cure for this virus. The only cure is prevention. It is only if you go out of your homes that you may bring the virus to your home and your neighbourhood,” said Patnaik.

He urged people to stay at home and come out only for basic services.

However, the establishments offering essential and emergency services like hospitals, clinics, medical shops, grocery shops, restaurants (only takeaways and home deliveries) vegetables, meat and milk shops/bread and bakery (but selling of tea and other beverages in the same premises have to be closed), railways, bus-stands, airports and public transport would remain open.

Besides, administration, police, health, fire, ODRAF, electricity, water, municipal services, banks, ATMs, petrol pumps shall remain open along with private establishments that support the aforesaid services or are linked to the fight against coronavirus.

Meanwhile, the benefits such as pension and PDS have been postponed for a temporary period in the above five districts and eight towns.

Title: Man booked for violating quarantine norms
Article:
The Commissionerate police on Sunday registered a case against a person in the Purighat police station area here for allegedly not following the guidelines after his return from the United States of America (USA).

The person, who registered for home quarantine after return from the US, was not following advice and was indulging in risky behaviour.

After the Health Department informed police, necessary verification was carried out. The person was found moving in market place, a statement issued by the Commissionerate police said.

Finding prima facie evidence, the Purighat police registered a case under Sections 188/269/270/271 IPC today and launched an investigation.

The person has been shifted to institutional quarantine, said police without disclosing his identity to protect privacy.

Title: Delhiites stay indoors
Article:
Roads in the national Capital wore a deserted look on Sunday as people joined hands to fight coronavirus by keeping themselves locked indoors. Barring public transport buses and emergency vehicles, a few private vehicles and buses were seen plying.

Autos and taxis were a rare sight due to the support extended by various unions representing such vehicles to Prime Minister Modi's appeal for Janta curfew. Several unions like the Delhi Autorickshaw Sangh, Delhi Pradesh Taxi Union, Delhi Auto Taxi Transport Congress Union and Delhi Taxi Tourist Transport Association supported the curfew call. Unions of last-mile connectivity vehicles also joined the curfew.

Delhi Metro services remained suspended and only 50 per cent of DTC and cluster buses were operational during the Janata curfew. Most of the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and cluster buses were seen running without any passengers. The inter-state bus terminals in the city too wore a deserted look. "No passengers or buses from any state were there at Kashmiri Gate, Sarai Kale Khan and Anand Vihar inter-state bus terminals," said a transport department official.

All major markets such as Connaught Place, Chandni Chowk, Bhagirath Place, Lajpat Rai Market, Khari Baoli, Kashmiri Gate, Sadar Bazar, Chawri Bazaar, Nai Sadak, Ajmeri Gate , Shraddhanand Marg and the retail markets of Delhi, mainly Karol Bagh, Kamla Nagar, Model Town, Azadpur, South Extension, Greater Kailash, Rohini, Shalimar Bagh, Pitampura, Rajouri Garden, Uttam Nagar, Tilak Nagar, Janakpuri, Patel Nagar, Kalkaji, Green Park, Khan Market, Tuglakabad, Vikas Marg, Preet Vihar, Laxmi Nagar, Gandhi Nagar, Krishna Nagar, Shahdara, Loni Road, Narela, Bawana, Azadpur, etc remained completely closed.

The inter-state private bus operators also suspended their operations in view of the Janata curfew. "The private buses plying between Delhi and other states also did not operate from 7 am onwards," said Shyamlal Gola, president of All India Luxury Bus Union. He said the union members will distribute one lakh masks and sanitisers to poor people at the three inter-state bus terminals in the city on Monday. Rajendra Soni, general secretary of Delhi Autorickshaw Sangh, said almost all the transport unions of the city have extended support to the prime minister's call of Janata curfew.

Even after medicine, dairy, food grains and grocery stores in colonies were kept free from the shutdown, were closed whole the day.

The Confederation of All India Trade (CAIT) national president BC Bhartia and Secretary General Praveen Khandelwal said that the three-day trade bandh call of Delhi traders by CAIT connected into Janata curfew o Sunday and all major and big markets of Delhi remained completely closed and there were no business activities in Delhi. The bandh in Delhi will continue on Monday also, it said.

The traders’ body has also sent a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi requesting to declare the national lockdown in the Country till March 31 to prevent any possibility of community transmission of coronavirus.

Title: Haryana Govt imposes lockdown
Article:
Streets, roads, Metro stations, Rapid Metro stations and public places in Gurugram wore a deserted look on Sunday as the ‘Janata curfew’ proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to prevent community transmission of the dreaded coronavirus.

Also on Sunday the Haryana Government ordered a complete lockdown. The lockdown will be imposed from 23 March till 31 March in 7 districts of the State which include Gurugram, Faridabad, Panchkula, Sonipat, Panipat Jhajjar and Rohtak.

During the lockdown, no public transport will operate but the essential services related to health, food, water and power supply will continue. Dairies, grocery shops, chemists and petrol pumps will remain open and persons associated with essential services will be allowed to go to their destinations during the lockdown.

On the other hand, during the 14-hour-long ‘Janata curfew’ is part of a social distancing exercise to help stop the spread of the virus. It began at 7 am and will last till at 9 pm.

Title: Petrol bomb thrown at Jamia, Shaheen protest sites
Article:
An unidentified man allegedly opened fire and hurled a petrol bomb at the empty protest site outside the Jamia Millia Islamia on Sunday, according to officials and students of the university. Also, petrol bombs were hurled at Shaheen Bagh protest site.

According to RP Meena, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), Southeast district, on Sunday at around 09:15 AM an information was received regarding firing by inflammable substance at barricades near Shaheen bagh.

"Acting on the information, a police team including Station House Officer (SHO) Shaheen Bagh visisted the spot. On spot a banner, dari and bamboo were found burnt. During initial investigation it was revealed that a person set banner on fire by pouring inflamable substance using a lighter," said the DCP.

"The spot was inspected by a team from the Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) and a cases have been registered under relevant sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) at the Jamia Nagar and Shaheen Bagh police stations. A broken bottle, a lighter and an empty cartridge were found from a spot near the divider of Gate No. 6 of Jamia Millia Islamia. Multiple teams were formed to trace the accused," said the DCP.

The Jamia Coordination Committee (JCC), comprising current and former students of the university, had temporarily suspended its sit-in protest against the new citizenship law on Saturday in view of the coronavirus outbreak.

In a statement, the JCC said a miscreant opened fire and hurled a petrol bomb at the protest site at Jamia Square, Gate No. 7 of the university. The statement added that CCTV footage showed the miscreant in the get-up of a delivery boy with a helmet and three bags on his bike, due to which its number plate was not visible. "Police have taken away the bullet, while pieces of a glass bottle are still there; it said.

According to a university official, the incident occurred around 9.30 am. The man came from the Okhla side, probably after committing a similar act at Shaheen Bagh. He hurled a bottle at the tent near Gate No. 7," he said. The tent was empty since the students had suspended the protest. As the tent did not catch fire, the man allegedly tried to set it ablaze using a lighter and fired a few rounds, the university official said, adding, "We informed the police about the incident and handed over the CCTV footage to them. He said after the incident, the miscreant fled towards Julena.

A similar incident occurred a few metres away at the Shaheen Bagh protest site, where an unidentified person allegedly hurled a petrol bomb. No one sustained injuries in the incident. Two unidentified persons had opened fire near one of the gates of the university last month. Before that, a minor had opened fire near the protest site, injuring one person.

Title: Women self-help groups produce eco-friendly, reusable masks
Article:
The women self-help groups (SHGs) in Surguja district have started manufacturing a cheaper, reusable and eco-friendly mask as part of its efforts to help curb the spread of the novel cornonavirus in the state

More than 25 SHGs of seven blocks of the district have started manufacturing three-layer cloth masks using locally-sourced materials, said district officials.

The cost of the mask is between Rs 15 and Rs 17, they said.

According to officials, the masks are being made by the SHGs from Ambikapur—Ekta, Santoshi, and Sai-Baba, Arti, Nari Shakti, Gayatri— and by the SHGs in Lakhanpur, Udaipur, Mainpat, Lundra, Batoli and Sitapur blocks of the distict.

According to district that Assistance is being provided under district bihan project, said project manager Rahul Mishra.

“The cloth masks can be used for 8 hours and then washed in water and anti-septic liquid, and can be used again,” Mishra said.

In also, women self-help groups from Dhamtari, too have started supplying eco-friendly cloth to the state health department for making of reusable masks.

The specialty of the reusable masks being provided to the health department, is that it is green in colour, which is scientifically approved, officials said.

It can be reused after washing, they said.

Women SHGs in Magarlod block too are producing eco-friendly masks.

The eco-friendly reusable masks ordered the state health department, can help in reducing the spread of the Covid-19 and other viral infections, said assistant district project officer Jai Verma.

“The eco-friendly masks procured by the department will be distributed in all the hospitals of district,” Verma said.

“The women in all the self-help groups have been have trained to make the mask,” he said.

Now, the project is being extended to other women self-help groups, especially in Balod, Bilaspur, Korba, Mungeli and other districts, to ensure the demand for masks is met and the sell it at a cheaper rate than the market price, the official said.

Title: Curfew extended to March 31
Article:
Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat held an emergency meeting with the chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, director general of police Anil Raturi, Finance Secretary Amit Negi and the Health and Home secretary Nitesh Jha on Sunday. It was decided in the meeting that the Janata Curfew which was successfully observed on Sunday will be enhanced to a lockdown till March 31.

Rawat said that considering the seriousness of the COVID-19 experience, the State Government has been decided that inter-state transport service and public transport within the state will be prohibited. However, institutions and shops providing essential services and goods related to health, food and other items will remain open.All district magistrates have been authorised to take decisions according to the local situation. All citizens are requested to remain in their city and locality.

The villagers should not come out of the villages except when very necessary. Rawat said, “I would like to tell the people that maintaining social distance is the most effective way to stall the spread of coronavirus.

The administration is alert in all places across the state. I have full faith that like citizens fully supported the Janata Curfew called by PM Narendra Modi, they will support us for the safety of the nation, state and their families.

The curfew till March 31 will not be applicable only on essential services. The Government will deposit Rs 1,000 each in the account of all registered labourers so that they are able to procure essential needs. I assure them that the Government will ensure that nobody remains hungry. Sanitisation is underway across the State. The Government is issuing directions on the basis of the experience and suggestions of experts from across the world. Read these carefully in newspapers, electronic media and observe the directions issued by health department, SDRF and other Government agencies. Anyone found spreading rumours on the social media will face penal action,” stressed the CM.

Title: Janata Curfew successful across State
Article:
The Janata Curfew was observed successfully in Dehradun and other parts of the State on Sunday. At 5 PM, citizens clapped, blew conch shells and banged plates in support of the health and other workers involved directly in tackling the pandemic situation. Governor Baby Rani Maurya and Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat also participated in this activity at their respective residences. The governor thanked the public for its cooperation and also appealed the citizens to follow the lockdown conditions implemented by the State Government till March 31.

In towns across the state including Dehradun, the roads were deserted as citizens remained indoors. While most of the people appreciated this move, some were skeptical about the effect of the curfew in breaking the chain of further spread of coronavirus.

According to Rudrapur resident Harish Bora, “The Janata Curfew was a smart decision by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and if further extended, we will completely support the decision.”

“It is good that our PM did not impose the curfew on the citizens but asked them to observe it voluntarily. It is a right decision but I do not think that all the people understand the gravity of the spread of coronavirus. Some people are still wandering around on the roads for apparently no reason. Therefore, I think the government should have imposed a compulsory curfew for all so that everyone will have to abide by it,” said Lokesh Sharma, a school teacher from Rajpur.

However, there were some who questioned the move. “The Janata Curfew is not logical at all. People cannot stay at home for weeks without job, salary or ration. The administration can help few people to manage the basic necessities like food or medicine but cannot pay the labourers who are dependent on their daily wages. The administration should understand that social distancing can be maintained even without a curfew,” said Rashid Khan, a store owner in Dalanwala. According to several locals who earn their livelihood as daily wagers or by selling vegetables and other items, the curfew hit them hard and if the condition is extended, they would face dire circumstances.

Title: Isolation wards & quarantine centre to be monitored from ICCC
Article:
The isolation wards made in Government hospitals and quarantine centres at hotels in Dehradun are being monitored from the Integrated Command and Control Centre (ICCC) at IT Park here. Dehradun Smart City Limited has made all arrangements for the monitoring with cameras and other equipment being installed in the hospitals and hotels.

The health department in Dehradun has set up isolation wards in four Government hospitals and a quarantine centre in one hotel. Isolation wards have been made in Government Doon Medical College hospital, Gandhi hospital, Coronation hospital and Subharti hospital while a quarantine centre has been made in Taqgene hotel. Orders have been issued to monitor these centres.

These will be monitored 24 hours from the ICCC which will enable monitoring of the patients and safety of others from the virus. Dehradun Smart City Limited chief executive officer Ashish Kumar Srivastava said that all possible efforts are being undertaken to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus in Dehradun.

Title: MCD sprays 1.5 lakh litres disinfectant to sanitise Doon
Article:
Amid the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) the Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD) ran a special campaign to sanitise the city on Sunday. According to deputy municipal commissioner Rohitash Sharma, the corporation used the opportunity provided by the Janata Curfew to sterilise the city as a precautionary measure against coronavirus.

The city was divided into eight zones for which eight nodal officers were given the charge to ensure the proper sanitisation. Sharma told The Pioneer that the people listened to the appeal of PM Narendra Modi and stayed indoor during most part of the day. He said, “Due to citizens observing Janata Curfew, we were able to spray disinfectant in the city without any hurdle. We started the work of spraying 1-Percentage Sodium Hypochlorite across the city in the morning and completed by 2 PM.” He further informed that 15 tanks of 3,000 litres disinfectants each were sprayed in the city besides 20 smaller tanks.

According to the chief municipal health officer Dr Kailash Joshi, all the major places where the people mainly gather were sanitised by MCD. Places including Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital, Coronation hospital, Banks, ATMs, offices of electricity and water departments, Inter State Bus Terminal (ISBT) and bus stations, were thoroughly sanitised. The corporation sprayed a total of 1.5 lakh litres of hypochlorite disinfectant to sanitise all the main public areas of the city, added Joshi. The task of sanitising the public places will be done regularly in the coming days as a preventive measure by MCD against coronavirus, he added.

Title: 5 returnees from Udaipur kept in isolation
Article:
Five students, including two girls who returned from Udaipur in Rajasthan after taking a course in hotel management, have been admitted to the isolation ward of the Mela hospital here. Their samples have been sent to Haldwani for tests as they were in touch with foreigners during their stay in Rajasthan. According to officials, five students returned from a hotel management course in a five-star hotel in Udaipur on Sunday.

They were screened and their travel history checked. The health department deemed it better to get them examained and kept in isolation ward.

The five including two girls sent to the Mela hospital include one each from Haridwar, Kotdwar, Dehradun and two from Pauri. They informed that during their training in Udaipur, they came in contact with travellers from abroad. Considering this, their samples were sent for examination and they were sent to isolation ward in the government hospital.

Title: Dept checking cause of woman’s death in Haridwar
Article:
A woman who had recently returned to Haridwar from USA died in Shivaliknagar on Sunday. The authorities have sent her sample for test to ascertain whether she died due to novel coronavirus. In the meantime, her family has been told to remain in quarantine.

The Health Department is treating the death of the lady suspicious as the cause is yet to be ascertained. The woman’s body was cremated on Sunday afternoon. According to the Haridwar chief medical officer Dr Saroj Naithani, the last rites were performed keeping in mind the guidelines of the Government of India and only five persons including the woman’s husband took the body to the crematorium. The 58 year old Saroj Chauhan had returned from USA on March 7 and also underwent a routine checkup in the district hospital on March 13.

On March 17, she started undergoing treatment from a personal physician after complaining of sore throat and cough but her condition deteriorated on Saturday evening. She died while being taken to the BHEL hospital on Sunday morning. The health department is monitoring the family.

Title: All passenger, express trains cancelled till Mar 31
Article:
In the wake of novel coronavirus spread in India, the Indian Railways has cancelled all the trains, except goods trains to maintain supply of essential services, till March 31.

“In continuation of the measures taken in the wake of COVID-19, it has been decided that the cancellation of all passenger train services on Indian Railways and Konkan Railway shall be extended till March 31. However, services like suburban trains and Kolkata Metro rail shall continue up to 24: 00 hrs till March 22,” , a Government statement said on Sunday.

It is estimated that around 13,523 trains will be affected with the decision as around 3, 947 passenger trains and 3,695 mail express services are being operated by the Indian Railways daily.

However, trains that had already commenced their journey, prior to 4.00 am on March 22 will run up to their destinations, the railways said.

The statement further said for those who have already booked train tickets, the Railways will provide full refund for all cancelled trains till March 21. "Adequate arrangements shall be made to facilitate hassle-free refund to passengers affected by train cancellations," it said in a statement.

Title: Indian Air Force reduces staff at headquarters
Article:
Amid the coronavirus scare, Indian Air Force issued directions to reduce attendance in its headquarters with effect from March 23, excluding personnel engaged in essential and emergency services directly involved in taking measures to control spread of COVID-19. Indian Air Force officials said it was also decided that 30 per cent of officers and 50 per cent of junior officers will work from home adhering to home quarantine for a week starting March 23.

Further it was also directed that a second group to proceed on home quarantine on March 30, 2020 and intermixing of groups to be avoided.

Two days ago, Indian Army had issued fresh advisory wherein posting of all Indian Army personnel were deferred and soldiers on leave were given extended leave till April 15.

Indian Army Chief General M.M. Naravane had reviewed the force's preparation to contain COVID-19 with important functionaries at Army headquarters as fresh instructions were issued

and strict adherence was demanded.

It was decided to run extensive awareness campaigns. "Awareness campaigns are being run on precautions to be taken within the Army and also for communities in near vicinity to Army establishments," said sources in the force.

All conferences and seminars were postponed till April 15 and temporary duty of all ranks are either rescheduled or cancelled till April 15.

All service personnel, except Army Medical Corps, attending courses terminating prior to April 15 will be retained at respective training institutions. For them additional training programmes can be added.

Further annual and periodic medical examinations have been postponed April 15. It has been decided to regulate entry to canteens and crowding and bunching will be completely avoided.

Title: SAARC Disaster Management launches website
Article:
As part of a plan to unleash coordinated actions to check the outbreak of coronavirus, the SAARC Disaster Management Centre has launched a website for information related to the pandemic in the region. This was proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi during the recent video conference with leaders and representatives of the member States.

The website shows the number of coronavirus cases in the member states, updating the numbers regularly.

"From regional plan to regional action! SAARC Disaster Management Centre launches a website for information related to COVID-19 pandemic in the SAARC region, as announced by PM Narendra Modi during the video conference with SAARC Leaders," Ministry of External Affairs Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar tweeted.

During the video conference last Sunday, Modi had called for using existing facilities, like the SAARC Disaster Management Centre, to pool in the best practices among all the member states to combat coronavirus.

"Looking ahead, we could create a common Research Platform, to coordinate research on controlling epidemic diseases within our South Asian region. The Indian Council of Medical Research can offer help coordinating such an exercise," the prime minister had said.

Modi had also proposed an emergency fund with an initial offer of $10 million from India. Apart from Modi, Bhutanese Prime Minister Lotay Tshering, Bangladesh premier Sheikh Hasina, Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Maldivian President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih, Nepalese Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli, Afghanistan President Ashraf Ghani and Special Assistant to Pakistani Prime Minister on Health Zafar Mirza, had participated in the conference.

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) is a regional intergovernmental organisation and geopolitical union of Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

Title: Coronavirus may reach you through air also!
Article:
People may acquire the deadly coronavirus through the air, a new study has suggested.

The scientists have discovered that the virus is detectable for up to three hours in aerosols, up to four hours on copper, up to 24 hours on cardboard and up to two to three days on plastic and stainless steel. An aerosol is a suspension of fine solid particles or liquid droplets in air or another gas.

"This virus is quite transmissible through relatively casual contact, making this pathogen very hard to contain," said James Lloyd-Smith, a co-author of the study and a UCLA professor of ecology and evolutionary biology. "If you're touching items that someone else has recently handled, be aware they could be contaminated and wash your hands."

The study attempted to mimic the virus being deposited onto everyday surfaces in a household or hospital setting by an infected person through coughing or touching objects, for example. The scientists then investigated how long the virus remained infectious on these surfaces.

The study's authors are from UCLA, the National Institutes of Health's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and Princeton University. They include Amandine Gamble, a UCLA postdoctoral researcher in Lloyd-Smith's laboratory.

In February, Lloyd-Smith and colleagues reported in the journal eLife that screening travelers for COVID-19 is not very effective. People infected with the virus — officially named SARS-CoV-2 — may be spreading the virus without knowing they have it or before symptoms appear.

Lloyd-Smith said the biology and epidemiology of the virus make infection extremely difficult to detect in its early stages because the majority of cases show no symptoms for five days or longer after exposure.

"Many people won't have developed symptoms yet," Lloyd-Smith said. "Based on our earlier analysis of flu pandemic data, many people may not choose to disclose if they do know."

Title: RS sees 106% productivity in second half of Budget Session
Article:
